perturbation.original_text: Women.com will name an area, in which eDiets content will be published (such area, the "Diet Center"). Links (presented as Diet Center logos) to the Diet Center will be located on three Women.com channels (the Fitness Channel www.women.com/fitness; the Health Channel www.women.com/health; and the Food Channel www.women.com/food) and two subchannels within such channels to be determined in accordance with Exhibit B hereto. The first page of the Diet Center (the "Gateway Page") will have the look and feel of the Women.com Sites as specified in Exhibit A hereto. The Diet Center shall be branded with an icon that includes the eDiets logo. There will be no Women.com or eDiets registration required to enter and use the Gateway Page of the Diet Center.
perturbation.changed_text: Women.com will name an area, in which eDiets content will be published (such area, the "Diet Center"). Links (presented as Diet Center logos) to the Diet Center will be located on three Women.com channels (the Fitness Channel www.women.com/fitness; the Health Channel www.women.com/health; and the Food Channel www.women.com/food) and two subchannels within such channels to be determined in accordance with Exhibit B hereto. The first page of the Diet Center (the "Entry Page") will have the look and feel of the Women.com Sites as specified in Exhibit A hereto. The Diet Center shall be branded with an icon that includes the eDiets logo. There will be no Women.com or eDiets registration required to enter and use the Entry Page of the Diet Center.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'Gateway Page' to 'Entry Page' creates ambiguity. 'Gateway Page' has a generally understood meaning in web agreements, referring to an initial access point. 'Entry Page' is less specific and could be interpreted differently, leading to disputes about which page the terms apply to. This would contradict standard practices and introduce legal uncertainty. Additionally, this affects other sections where the term is used, creating a conflict.

perturbation.original_text: During the Term, Women.com agrees to give eDiets the right of first refusal to participate in all diet and diet-counseling related promotion opportunities created or otherwise made available by Women.com on channels or sub-channels created after the Effective Date of this Agreement, including sponsorships, anchor placements and any other content integration opportunities ("Diet Promos"). If Women.com proposes to create and make available Diet Promos after the Effective Date, it shall give eDiets written notice of its intention, describing the terms and conditions of participation in the Diet Promos. eDiets shall have fifteen (15) days from the giving of such notice to agree to participate in the applicable Diet Promo upon the terms and conditions specified in the notice by giving written notice of its agreement to Women.com.
perturbation.changed_text: During the Term, Women.com agrees to give eDiets preferential consideration to participate in all diet and diet-counseling related promotion opportunities created or otherwise made available by Women.com on channels or sub-channels created after the Effective Date of this Agreement, including sponsorships, anchor placements and any other content integration opportunities ("Diet Promos"). If Women.com proposes to create and make available Diet Promos after the Effective Date, it shall give eDiets written notice of its intention, describing the terms and conditions of participation in the Diet Promos. eDiets shall have fifteen (15) days from the giving of such notice to agree to participate in the applicable Diet Promo upon the terms and conditions specified in the notice by giving written notice of its agreement to Women.com.
perturbation.explanation: Replacing 'right of first refusal' with 'preferential consideration' significantly weakens eDiets' position. 'Right of first refusal' is a legally recognized term creating a clear obligation. 'Preferential consideration' is vague and subjective, allowing Women.com to potentially offer the opportunity to others even if eDiets expresses interest. This creates a legal contradiction by misrepresenting the strength of eDiets' entitlement, and contradicting standard contract definitions.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Right of First Refusal

perturbation.original_text: Confidential Information of the Disclosing Party will not include information that the Disclosing Party can demonstrate by reasonable evidence (a) is in or enters the public domain without breach of this Agreement, (b) the Receiving Party lawfully receives from a third party without restriction on disclosure and without breach of a nondisclosure obligation, (c) is approved for release by written authorization of the Disclosing Party, (d) the Receiving Party knew prior to receiving such information from the Disclosing Party or (e) is independently developed by the Receiving Party without reference to Confidential Information of the Disclosing Party.
perturbation.changed_text: Confidential Information of the Disclosing Party will not include information that the Disclosing Party alleges with some proof (a) is in or enters the public domain without breach of this Agreement, (b) the Receiving Party lawfully receives from a third party without restriction on disclosure and without breach of a nondisclosure obligation, (c) is approved for release by written authorization of the Disclosing Party, (d) the Receiving Party knew prior to receiving such information from the Disclosing Party or (e) is independently developed by the Receiving Party without reference to Confidential Information of the Disclosing Party.
perturbation.explanation: Changing "reasonable evidence" to "alleges with some proof" weakens the standard of proof required by the disclosing party. Legally, 'reasonable evidence' suggests a degree of objectivity and verifiability. 'Alleges with some proof' is more subjective and could be satisfied with minimal or unsubstantiated claims. This change contradicts the established legal understanding of proving exceptions to confidentiality, potentially undermining the confidentiality provisions of the contract, since, the receiving party can make a unsubstantiated claim about the information.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Burden of Proof in Confidentiality
